<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: Yes, you are correct. In order to implement the Iterator interface, you should define a separate inner class that implements the Iterator interface and contains the hasNext(), next(), and remove() methods. The iterator() method in your LinkedList class should return an instance of this inner class. Here is an example of how you can define the inner class:

public class LinkedList<T> implements Iterable<T> {

    // LinkedList implementation

    private class LinkedListIterator implements Iterator<T> {

        // Implement hasNext(), next(), and remove() methods here

    }

    @Override
    public Iterator<T> iterator() {
        return new LinkedListIterator();
    }

    // Other methods in LinkedList class

}

By defining a separate inner class for the iterator, you can encapsulate the iterator logic and provide a clean separation between the LinkedList implementation and the iterator implementation.
